results.title: The Long distance search for the great Australian funny bone. - Edited version
results.brief_description: A variety of yarns and tall stories are told in this edited version of the search for the key to Australian humour. Includes animated sequences. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Log raft: a Norwegian summer story
results.creator_credit: Karin Sandberg, Sverre Sandberg and Svekon Films
results.brief_description: Three young children spend the summer at their island cabin at the fjords. Their love of nature makes their experience universal but their curiosity leads to some dramatic moments. A strange surreal quality film with excellent close-up photography.

results.title: The Living mammal
results.brief_description: Common characteristics held by all mammals. Various ways in which mammals have adapted themselves to life in the water, air, treetops and on the ground. The highly developed senses of sight, smell, touch and hearing combined in the hunt for food. The adaptations of teeth for herbivorous, carnivorous and ominivorous modes of life. Methods of self-protection and ways in which different mammals care for and rear their young.

results.title: The Living bird
results.brief_description: The bird as a living creature. Its power of flight, structure, metabolism, senses of sight, smell and hearing. Remarkable scenes show bird courtship, nesting and the hatching of eggs of both altricial and precocious types.

results.title: The Lion in the doorway
results.creator_credit: Prabhubodha Walker, Christina Ferguson, Macau Light Films and O J Productions
results.brief_description: A satirical, experimental, metaphysical western. A cowboy figure joins those of Icarus and Pierrot and encounters some less than lovely aspects of wild west culture.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Prabhubodha Walker, Christina Ferguson, Macau Light Films and O J Productions

results.title: The Lion and the mouse
results.brief_description: Through an amusing cartoon interpretation of an Aesopean fable, children learn that size alone does not determine how helpful a person can be. We see the king of the jungle, a lion, laugh at the idea that a tiny mouse could ever help him. But when a speck of dirt gets into the lion’s eye, it is the little mouse who removes it and proves to be a helpful friend after all.

results.title: The Light
results.brief_description:
Brian Doyle’s award-winning videos, installations and photos have been shown in galleries and film festivals throughout America and Europe. His latest body of work Yestermorrow (2000), Current (2001) and The Light
(2003) use the pretext of a developing storm to expose the ephemeral forces at play around us. Doyle documents phenomena that routinely affect our lives, uncovering alternate layers of reality below the surface of our recognition. Doyle’s collision of nature and culture invest everyday occurrences and familiar spaces with an otherworldly aura.

Doyle filmed across the United States in New York, Florida and Nevada, but The Light ultimately describes a non-place. Journeying from the countryside to urban construction grounds and the illumination of New York, light becomes a powerful metaphor for humanity’s struggle, through technology and determination,
to ‘pierce the night and see through the darkness’.

Beginning with the most simple of structures, a glowing street lamp, The Light gracefully charts a procession of increasingly complex illuminations. The film slowly builds toward the memorial light columns of the World Trade Center, which are shown not in direct conjunction with 9/11 but as the formal and abstracted transcendence of pure light.

(SW 30.03.05)
